articles.title: Sunlight Extracts Oxygen From Regolith Using Solar Chemistry
articles.summary: NASA’s Carbothermal Reduction Demonstration (CaRD) project completed an important step toward using local resources to support human exploration on the Moon. The CaRD team performed integrated prototype testing that used concentrated solar energy to extract oxygen from simulated lunar soil, while confirming the production of carbon monoxide through a solar-driven chemical reaction.  If deployed on the Moon, this technology could enable the production of propellant using […]
articles.content:
A solar concentrator is tested as part of the Carbothermal Reduction Demonstration (CaRD) project, which aims to produce oxygen from simulated lunar regolith for use at the Moon’s south pole. During this integrated test, the team combined the concentrator, mirrors, and control software and confirmed the production of carbon monoxide. NASA/Michael Rushing

NASA’s Carbothermal Reduction Demonstration (CaRD) project completed an important step toward using local resources to support human exploration on the Moon. The CaRD team performed integrated prototype testing that used concentrated solar energy to extract oxygen from simulated lunar soil, while confirming the production of carbon monoxide through a solar-driven chemical reaction.

If deployed on the Moon, this technology could enable the production of propellant using only lunar materials and sunlight, significantly reducing the cost and complexity of sustaining a long-term human presence on the lunar surface. The same downstream systems used to convert carbon monoxide into oxygen can also be adapted to convert carbon dioxide into oxygen and methane on Mars.

The integrated prototype brought together a carbothermal oxygen production reactor developed by Sierra Space, a solar concentrator designed by NASA’s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland, precision mirrors produced by Composite Mirror Applications, and avionics, software, and gas analysis systems from NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston led project management, systems engineering, testing, and development of key hardware and ground support systems.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant technological breakthrough by NASA in extracting oxygen from lunar soil using solar energy, which has broad implications for sustainable human exploration on the Moon and Mars. This innovation could reduce costs and complexity of long-term space missions, representing a meaningful advancement in space exploration technology with tangible benefits for humanity's future in space.
articles.personality_title: NASA uses sunlight to turn moon soil into oxygen
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is working on ways to use materials found on the Moon to help astronauts live and work there. One big challenge is making oxygen, which people need to breathe and to fuel rockets.

**What happened** – NASA’s Carbothermal Reduction Demonstration (CaRD) project successfully tested a system that uses strong sunlight focused by mirrors to pull oxygen out of fake moon soil. This test combined parts made by different NASA centers and companies, including a special reactor, mirrors, and computer controls. The process also created carbon monoxide, confirming the chemical reaction worked.

**Impact** – This technology is important because it could let astronauts make oxygen and rocket fuel directly on the Moon using just moon soil and sunlight. That means missions won’t have to carry as much oxygen from Earth, making space travel cheaper and easier. The same idea might also work on Mars to make oxygen and fuel there.

**What's next step** – NASA will continue improving this system and test it in more realistic conditions. The goal is to eventually send it to the Moon to support astronauts living there for a long time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA has made a key step toward using sunlight and moon soil to create oxygen, helping future space missions become more self-sufficient.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA utilise la lumière du soleil pour extraire de l’oxygène du sol lunaire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA cherche des moyens d’utiliser les ressources de la Lune pour aider les astronautes à y vivre et travailler. Un grand défi est de produire de l’oxygène, nécessaire pour respirer et pour le carburant des fusées.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le projet Carbothermal Reduction Demonstration (CaRD) de la NASA a réussi à tester un système qui utilise la lumière solaire concentrée par des miroirs pour extraire de l’oxygène du sol lunaire simulé. Ce test a réuni des pièces fabriquées par différents centres et entreprises, dont un réacteur spécial, des miroirs et des commandes informatiques. La production de monoxyde de carbone a aussi été confirmée, prouvant que la réaction chimique fonctionnait.

**Impact** – Cette technologie est importante car elle pourrait permettre aux astronautes de fabriquer de l’oxygène et du carburant directement sur la Lune en utilisant seulement le sol lunaire et la lumière du soleil. Cela signifie que les missions n’auront pas besoin d’emporter autant d’oxygène depuis la Terre, rendant les voyages spatiaux moins coûteux et plus simples. La même idée pourrait aussi être appliquée sur Mars.

**Prochaine étape** – La NASA va continuer à améliorer ce système et le tester dans des conditions plus proches de la réalité. L’objectif est de l’envoyer un jour sur la Lune pour soutenir les astronautes qui y vivront longtemps.

**En une phrase** – La NASA a fait un pas important pour utiliser la lumière du soleil et le sol lunaire afin de produire de l’oxygène, aidant les futures missions spatiales à devenir plus autonomes.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA usa la luz solar para extraer oxígeno del suelo lunar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA está buscando formas de usar los recursos de la Luna para ayudar a los astronautas a vivir y trabajar allí. Un gran desafío es producir oxígeno, que las personas necesitan para respirar y para el combustible de los cohetes.

**Qué pasó** – El proyecto Carbothermal Reduction Demonstration (CaRD) de la NASA probó con éxito un sistema que usa luz solar concentrada con espejos para sacar oxígeno del suelo lunar simulado. Esta prueba combinó piezas hechas por diferentes centros y empresas, incluyendo un reactor especial, espejos y controles informáticos. También se confirmó la producción de monóxido de carbono, mostrando que la reacción química funcionó.

**Impacto** – Esta tecnología es importante porque podría permitir a los astronautas hacer oxígeno y combustible directamente en la Luna usando solo el suelo lunar y la luz del sol. Esto significa que las misiones no tendrán que llevar tanto oxígeno desde la Tierra, haciendo los viajes espaciales más baratos y fáciles. La misma idea podría funcionar también en Marte.

**Próximo paso** – La NASA seguirá mejorando este sistema y probándolo en condiciones más reales. El objetivo es enviarlo a la Luna para ayudar a los astronautas que vivirán allí por mucho tiempo.

articles.title: Huge hot blobs inside Earth may have made its magnetic field wonky
articles.summary: Simulations suggest that two enormous masses of hot rock have been involved in generating Earth’s magnetic field and giving it an irregular shape
articles.content:
Simulations suggest that two enormous masses of hot rock have been involved in generating Earth’s magnetic field and giving it an irregular shape

Earth’s magnetic field extends tens of thousands of kilometres into space Getty Images/iStockphoto

Two vast, mysterious blobs of hot rock around Earth’s core may have been instrumental in producing Earth’s magnetic field and caused it to be slightly wonky for millions of years.

Scientists have known for decades about two peculiar continent-sized chunks of rock, one beneath Africa and the other under the Pacific Ocean. These blobs, which extend nearly 1000 kilometres from the outer core to the rocky mantle above, must be different from their surroundings because seismic waves travel through them more slowly. But as it is difficult to measure them due to their depth, scientists can’t identify exactly how they differ.

Andrew Biggin at the University of Liverpool, UK, and his colleagues looked to Earth’s magnetic field for clues. This field has been generated for billions of years by the churning of molten iron within our planet’s core. It extends tens of thousands of kilometres into space, protecting us from solar wind and cosmic radiation.

The exact shape and form of this magnetic field is determined by the amount of energy, in the form of heat, that moves from the hot core to cooler regions around it. Biggin and his team theorised that by studying how the magnetic field has changed, they could learn about how heat has moved through Earth’s core.

The researchers collated records of ancient volcanic rocks that have preserved the direction of Earth’s magnetic field at several different points over the past tens or hundreds of millions of years, to gather a picture of how Earth’s magnetic field has changed over time. Then, they ran simulations of how heat flowing through the planet’s core and mantle produced a magnetic field, for scenarios both with and without the giant blobs of hot rock, and compared it with the real magnetic field readings.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

They found that the simulation with the blobs of rock best matched the ancient magnetic data. “These simulations of the convection that’s happening in the core, that’s generating the magnetic field, can reproduce some of the salient features of the [magnetic] field, but only when you impose this strong heterogeneity in the amount of heat that’s flowing out of the top of the core,” says Biggin.

In other words, these regions have probably been much hotter than the regions around them for hundreds of millions of years, and caused heat flow between the core and the mantle to decrease. This different heat flow would have helped produce and stabilise Earth’s magnetic field, according to the team’s simulations.

Most geologists assume that, over millions of years, Earth’s magnetic field has been essentially symmetrical, similar to a bar magnet used in a compass. But Biggin and his team also found that the ancient magnetic field wasn’t symmetrical, on average, and contained systematic deviations that persisted over millions of years, which also appear to be a result of these blobs of rocks. This could have implications for how geologists calculate the movement of ancient rocks and tell us about how Earth’s deep structures have changed over time, says Biggin.

If the team’s findings are correct, then the temperature difference found in the blobs might also exist at points in Earth’s uppermost outer core, which could be detectable via seismic waves, says Biggin.

But this would be extremely difficult to capture, says Sanne Cottaar at the University of Cambridge. “I have my doubts,” she says. “It’s very challenging for us to map variations within the core, given we have to look through so much mantle material before we see it.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about Earth's magnetic field generation involving large hot rock blobs inside Earth, which helps us better understand planetary magnetic fields and Earth's deep interior. This has broad implications for geoscience and planetary science, offering meaningful insights into Earth's protective magnetic shield that benefits all life.
articles.personality_title: Giant hot rock blobs inside Earth shape its magnetic field
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Earth’s magnetic field protects us from harmful space radiation and is created by movements inside Earth’s core. Scientists have long known about two huge, hot rock blobs deep inside Earth, but their role was unclear.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University of Liverpool studied ancient volcanic rocks and ran computer simulations to see how heat moves inside Earth’s core and mantle. They found that including the two big hot rock blobs in their models matched the real magnetic field changes seen over millions of years.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that the blobs have likely been hotter than surrounding areas for hundreds of millions of years, affecting how heat flows inside Earth. This uneven heat flow helps create and stabilize Earth’s magnetic field and explains why the field is not perfectly symmetrical. It also offers new clues about how Earth’s deep interior works and how ancient rock movements are understood.

**What’s next step** – Scientists hope to detect temperature differences caused by these blobs deeper in Earth’s outer core using seismic waves, though this will be very challenging. More detailed studies could improve our understanding of Earth’s interior and magnetic field.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Two massive hot rock blobs inside Earth help shape and stabilize its magnetic field by changing how heat moves inside the planet.
articles.personality_title_fr: D’énormes masses de roche chaude à l’intérieur de la Terre influencent son champ magnétique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le champ magnétique de la Terre nous protège des radiations spatiales dangereuses et est créé par des mouvements à l’intérieur du noyau terrestre. Les scientifiques connaissent depuis longtemps deux énormes masses de roche chaude très profondes dans la Terre, mais leur rôle restait inconnu.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Liverpool ont étudié des roches volcaniques anciennes et réalisé des simulations informatiques pour comprendre comment la chaleur circule dans le noyau et le manteau terrestres. Ils ont découvert qu’en incluant ces deux grandes masses chaudes dans leurs modèles, les changements du champ magnétique observés depuis des millions d’années étaient mieux expliqués.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que ces masses étaient probablement plus chaudes que les zones autour depuis des centaines de millions d’années, ce qui influence la circulation de la chaleur à l’intérieur de la Terre. Ce flux de chaleur irrégulier aide à créer et stabiliser le champ magnétique terrestre et explique pourquoi ce champ n’est pas parfaitement symétrique. Cela apporte aussi de nouvelles informations sur le fonctionnement profond de la Terre et sur les mouvements anciens des roches.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques espèrent détecter les différences de température causées par ces masses dans le noyau externe de la Terre grâce aux ondes sismiques, bien que ce soit très difficile. Des études plus détaillées pourraient améliorer notre compréhension de l’intérieur de la Terre et de son champ magnétique.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Deux énormes masses de roche chaude à l’intérieur de la Terre influencent et stabilisent son champ magnétique en modifiant la circulation de la chaleur à l’intérieur de la planète.
articles.personality_title_es: Grandes masas de roca caliente dentro de la Tierra moldean su campo magnético
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El campo magnético de la Tierra nos protege de la radiación espacial dañina y se crea por movimientos dentro del núcleo terrestre. Los científicos han conocido por mucho tiempo dos enormes masas de roca caliente en lo profundo de la Tierra, pero no sabían su papel exacto.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Liverpool estudiaron rocas volcánicas antiguas y realizaron simulaciones por computadora para entender cómo se mueve el calor dentro del núcleo y el manto de la Tierra. Descubrieron que al incluir estas dos grandes masas calientes en sus modelos, podían explicar mejor los cambios en el campo magnético observados durante millones de años.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo muestra que estas masas probablemente han estado más calientes que las zonas a su alrededor durante cientos de millones de años, afectando el flujo de calor dentro de la Tierra. Este flujo irregular ayuda a crear y estabilizar el campo magnético y explica por qué el campo no es perfectamente simétrico. También da nuevas pistas sobre cómo funciona el interior profundo de la Tierra y el movimiento antiguo de las rocas.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos esperan detectar diferencias de temperatura causadas por estas masas en el núcleo externo de la Tierra usando ondas sísmicas, aunque será muy difícil. Estudios más detallados podrían mejorar nuestro conocimiento del interior de la Tierra y su campo magnético.

**Una frase clave** – Dos grandes masas de roca caliente dentro de la Tierra ayudan a formar y estabilizar su campo magnético al cambiar cómo circula el calor dentro del planeta.
